comments.message: If the black cloth "shadow nets" (see photo above) used by MSF cool off the tent, would reflective surfaces on the tops of the tents (painted or tarps) cool it even more ????

Hi Rebecca,directly cooling the PPE is difficult. So all that can be done to reduce the temperatures in the vicinity of the workers in PPE should be done. And I think it is possible to find solutions that can be applied fast.With kind regards,Rainer
Thanks.Shane & Rainer, How do you see the possibilities for using passive techniques for cooling spaces getting communicated to the people setting up the field hospital tents ?

Great point Rebecca. Using passive cooling to reduce temperatures in work environments can help alleviate heat strain for healthcare workers in PPE suits. You should check out the Butaro Hospital that was designed and built by the MASS Design group in Rawanda. The design used natural ventilation and layout strategies to reduce the transmission of airborne diseases - which also significantly reduced the temperature of patient wards through passive cooling. The hospital was built from what was available locally - in terms of using local materials and building techniques. http://www.archdaily.com/165892/butaro-hospital-mass-design-group/

Hi Shane and Rainer, here's another example of Shane's recommended design firm for passive cooling (last slide)  http://www.wired.com/2013/11/design-for-the-developing-world/#slideid-321021 Would they be in contact with the actors on the ground already ? If not, who could connect them ?
